taskTitle: Assess and Manage Changes to Scope, Schedule and Costs

quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're managing a construction project: 12-month timeline, $2M budget, 3-story office building. Midway through (month 6), the customer requests a 4th floor (additional scope). The customer says: 'It won't take much longer.' Your estimate: 4 additional months and $500K extra cost. The customer hasn't authorized change, but wants you to 'see if we can fit it in.' Your team is asking: 'Do we start planning this or not?'
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What should you do FIRST?

options.A: Tell the team to plan for the 4th floor since the customer requested it
options.B: Ignore the request‚Äîstick to the original scope
options.C: Run impact analysis: scope impact (4 floors), schedule impact (+4 months), cost impact (+$500K), then present to customer for formal approval/rejection
options.D: Start building the 4th floor and present the cost overrun later

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: C - Assess impacts, present options, get formal approval

insights.explanation: Scope changes ALWAYS affect schedule and cost. Customer requests sound small ('It won't take much longer'), but analysis reveals truth: +4 months, +$500K. You MUST show impacts.
insights.pmbokSupport: Assess impacts of all change requests on scope, schedule, and cost before approval

insights.explanation: If you let customers slip in changes without formal approval, suddenly the 12-month/2M project becomes 16-month/2.5M project. Then EVERYONE is unhappy.
insights.pmbokSupport: Implement formal change management process; all changes require analysis and approval

insights.explanation: You need clear original scope (3 floors), schedule (12 months), cost ($2M) to measure IMPACT. Without baselines, you can't assess anything.
insights.pmbokSupport: Maintain scope, schedule, and cost baselines to measure deviations

trapSection.explanation: Mishandling change management or being too flexible with scope.

trapTable.option: A - Plan for scope without formal approval
trapTable.violation: You're planning a 4th floor that's not approved. Wasted planning effort; team confusion.
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Lack of change control; scope creep

trapTable.violation: You discover after 2 months that 4th floor is truly impossible, but you've already started. Disaster.
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: No planning; reactive instead of proactive

checklist: Is this a scope change? (adding something not in original plan)
What's the schedule impact? (How many extra months/weeks?)
What's the cost impact? (How much extra budget?)
Do I have formal approval to proceed with assessment?
Have I presented options to the customer/sponsor for decision?
patternRecognition.patternRule: ANY scope change ‚Üí Always assess schedule AND cost impacts ‚Üí Present to customer/sponsor ‚Üí Wait for FORMAL approval before executing.

coreFramework.frameworkName: ASSESS Framework for Managing Scope, Schedule, and Cost Changes
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Managing changes requires rigorous analysis and formal approval:

rows.action: Clearly define what's being requested. 4th floor? New features? Different requirements? Be specific before assessing impact.
keyQuestions: How does it differ from original scope?
rows.examKeywords: Change request, scope change, requirement clarification

rows.action: How much NEW work is required? For a 4th floor: structural design, permits, materials, labor, inspections. Quantify the scope addition.
rows.examKeywords: Scope impact, scope creep, work breakdown, deliverables

rows.action: How many months/weeks will the new scope require? Original: 12 months for 3 floors. 4th floor estimate: +4 months. New timeline: 16 months.
keyQuestions: How long will this addition take?
rows.examKeywords: Schedule impact, delay, timeline, critical path

rows.action: What's the budget impact? Materials, labor, equipment, contingency. Original: $2M. 4th floor: +$500K. New budget: $2.5M.
keyQuestions: Do we have budget for this?
rows.examKeywords: Cost impact, budget variance, estimates, funding

rows.action: Present to customer: 'Option A: Add 4th floor = 16 months, $2.5M. Option B: Stick with 3 floors = 12 months, $2M. Which do you choose?' Require formal approval.
rows.examKeywords: Approval, decision, stakeholder consensus, formal authorization

pmbokConnection.principle: Principle 8: Manage Scope, Schedule, and Costs
pmbokConnection.quote: Effective project management requires assessing impacts of ALL changes on scope, schedule, and cost before approval

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Change management essentials:** Clarify request | Assess scope impact | Assess schedule impact | Assess cost impact | Present options | Get approval
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: No scope change without analyzing its schedule and cost impacts. Present options to customer, get formal approval, THEN execute.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'scope change,' 'change request,' or 'customer wants...' ‚Üí Assess scope, schedule, AND cost impacts ‚Üí Present to customer ‚Üí Require formal approval.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Integrate Scope, Schedule, Cost - Any change to one affects the others

secondScenario.title: Apply ASSESS Framework
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your software development project is in sprint 4 of 8 (8-month total, $1.2M budget). Customer asks for a new payment gateway integration (originally planned for phase 2). PM estimate: 3 sprints of development + testing + integration = 6 weeks, $80K. Current burn rate suggests no buffer. Customer says: 'Can we fit it in?'
secondScenario.question: What should you do?

options.A: Start the integration immediately to keep customer happy
options.B: Assess impact: +6 weeks schedule, +$80K cost, evaluate if it fits in 8-month timeline and $1.2M budget, then present options to customer
options.C: Defer it to phase 2 as originally planned without discussing with customer

quotes.text: Change management is going to be a hot topic on your exam‚Äîexpect 10+ questions. Every change affects scope, schedule, and cost. You MUST assess all three impacts, present options to the customer, and get formal approval before executing.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Project managers manage changes to scope, schedule, and cost through a formal change control process. All changes must be assessed and approved before implementation.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Triple Constraint or Iron Triangle
fieldInsights.insight: Every project has three constraints: Scope, Schedule, Cost. Change one, and the others are affected. More scope ‚Üí longer timeline or higher cost. You can't just say 'yes' to scope changes without addressing the trade-offs.

personalApplication.title: Personal Reflection

questions.question: What scope changes are being requested on your current project?
questions.placeholder: Example: Adding new feature, changing requirements, expanding deliverables...

personalApplication.valueStatement: Formal change management protects projects. The customers who respect change control end up happier than those who don't.

memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Mountain Expedition Scope Changes

story.title: Managing Unexpected Summit Requests
story.narrative: You planned a 20,000-foot expedition (12 weeks, $50K budget). Midway through, your customer says: 'Can we also summit two nearby 18,000-foot peaks?' You didn't plan for this. How do you respond?

scenes.description: Customer wants: Main 20K peak + two 18K peaks. That's not the original plan. Clarify: Is this adding the peaks to the route, or a separate expedition?
Original scope: Route to 20K summit. Additional scope: Planning/climbing two 18K peaks, additional camps, guides, supplies. That's significant new work.
Original: 12 weeks to 20K summit. Adding two 18K peaks: +4 weeks (divert from main route, summit peaks, return to main route). New timeline: 16 weeks.
Additional guides, camps, supplies for 4 weeks: +$15K. New total budget: $50K + $15K = $65K. Customer only budgeted $50K.
Tell customer: 'Option A: 20K only = 12 weeks, $50K. Option B: 20K + two 18K = 16 weeks, $65K. Which choice?' Wait for formal approval before changing the expedition.

story.moral: ASSESS framework: Route guide Analyzes request, checks Scope impact, Evaluates Schedule, Sums Cost, and Explains options to climber. Customer approves choice BEFORE execution. That's how changes are managed professionally.
